name: Birch–Tate conjecture
summary: The Birch–Tate conjecture is a proposal in algebraic K-theory that relates the value of the Dedekind zeta-function of a totally real number field to the order of its K2-group. It states that the order of the algebraic K2-group of the ring of integers for a totally real number field is equal to the absolute value of the zeta-function evaluated at \(-1\), potentially with a power of two adjustment. This conjecture has been confirmed for certain cases but remains an open problem in mathematics.
head: The order (number of elements) of the algebraic K-group \(K_{2}(\mathcal{O}_{F})\) of the ring of integers \(\mathcal{O}_{F}\) of a totally real number field \(F\) is a certain value.

The value of the Dedekind zeta function \(\zeta _{F}(s)\) of the field \(F\) at \(s=-1\) is related to the order of the \(K_{2}\) group by a specific formula involving a power of 2 and some other factors.
